article:
2022 Rajya Sabha Elections

The 2022 Rajya Sabha elections were held to elect 57 members to the Rajya Sabha, the upper house of the Parliament of India. The elections were held on June 10, 2022, and the counting of votes took place on the same day.

List of Elections by States

The 2022 Rajya Sabha elections were held in 15 states across India. The states and the number of seats up for election are listed below:

* Andhra Pradesh (4)
* Assam (3)
* Bihar (5)
* Chhattisgarh (2)
* Himachal Pradesh (1)
* Haryana (2)
* Jharkhand (2)
* Karnataka (4)
* Kerala (3)
* Madhya Pradesh (3)
* Maharashtra (6)
* Nagaland (1)
* Odisha (4)
* Punjab (2)
* Rajasthan (4)
* Tamil Nadu (6)
* Telangana (2)
* Tripura (1)
* Uttar Pradesh (11)
* Uttarakhand (1)

article:
2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification

The 2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification is a series of association football matches that will be contested to determine the participating teams for the 2024 AFC U-23 Asian Cup. A total of 16 teams will qualify for the final tournament, with Uzbekistan qualifying automatically as hosts.

Format changes
-------------

The qualification process has been modified from the previous edition. The number of participating teams has been increased from 43 to 44, with the addition of Northern Mariana Islands. The qualification process will consist of a group stage, followed by a ranking of the runners-up teams to determine the remaining berths.

Draw
-----

The draw for the qualification groups was held on 2 June 2022 at the AFC House in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The 44 teams were divided into 11 groups of four teams each. The teams were seeded based on their performance in the 2022 AFC U-23 Asian Cup qualification.

### Draw result

The draw resulted in the following groups:

* Group A: Jordan, Syria, Lebanon, Turkmenistan
* Group B: Australia, China, Laos, Solomon Islands
* Group C: South Korea, Malaysia, Thailand, Mongolia
* Group D: Japan, Vietnam, Myanmar, Guam
* Group E: Iraq, Bahrain, Kuwait, Afghanistan
* Group F: United Arab Emirates, Oman, Qatar, Nepal
* Group G: North Korea, Hong Kong, Singapore, Brunei
* Group H: India, Uzbekistan, Bangladesh, Maldives
* Group I: Palestine, Saudi Arabia, Yemen, Sri Lanka
* Group J: Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan, Iran, Pakistan
* Group K: Indonesia, Cambodia, East Timor, Northern Mariana Islands

Format
--------

The qualification process will consist of a group stage, with each team playing the other teams in their group once. The top team from each group will qualify for the final tournament. The remaining berths will be determined by a ranking of the runners-up teams.

### Tiebreakers

In the event that two or more teams are tied on points, the following tiebreakers will be used to determine the ranking:

* Goal difference
* Goals scored
* Head-to-head result
* Drawing of lots

article:
2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup

The 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup is the 23rd edition of the FIFA U-20 World Cup, the biennial international men's youth football championship contested by the under-20 national teams of the member associations of FIFA. The tournament is scheduled to take place in Argentina from May 20 to June 11, 2023.

#Host selection

The bidding process for the 2023 FIFA U-20 World Cup was launched in September 2019. Indonesia was initially awarded the hosting rights in October 2019, but due to concerns over the country's ability to host the tournament, the decision was later reversed in March 2023. Argentina was subsequently chosen as the new host country.

#Qualified teams

A total of 24 teams qualify for the final tournament. In addition to Argentina, who qualify automatically as hosts, the remaining 23 teams are determined through six separate qualifying competitions. The qualified teams are:

* Asia: Japan, South Korea, Uzbekistan, and Iraq
* Africa: Senegal, Nigeria, Tunisia, and Gambia
* North and Central America and the Caribbean: United States, Honduras, Mexico, and Dominican Republic
* South America: Brazil, Uruguay, Colombia, and Ecuador
* Europe: France, Italy, England, Israel, and Slovakia
* Oceania: New Zealand and Fiji

#Venues

The tournament features six venues across Argentina. The venues are:

* Estadio Monumental Antonio Vespucio Liberti in Buenos Aires
* Estadio Alberto J. Armando in Buenos Aires
* Estadio Eva Perón in Junín
* Estadio Pedro Bidegain in Buenos Aires
* Estadio Juan Domingo Perón in Córdoba
* Estadio Marcelo A. Bielsa in Rosario

#Draw

The draw for the tournament took place on April 21, 2023, at the FIFA headquarters in Zurich, Switzerland. The 24 teams are divided into six groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group and the four best third-placed teams advancing to the knockout stage.

#Match officials

A total of 17 referees, 30 assistant referees, and 20 video assistant referees are appointed for the tournament.

#Squads

Each team is allowed to submit a squad of 21 players, with three goalkeepers. The squads are announced on May 10, 2023.

#Group stage

The group stage features 36 matches, with each team playing the other teams in their group once. The teams earn three points for a win, one point for a draw, and zero points for a loss.

##Tiebreakers

If two or more teams are tied on points, the following tiebreakers are used:

* Goal difference
* Total goals scored
* Head-to-head result
* Drawing of lots

##Group A

| Pos | Team | Pld | W | D | L | GF | GA | GD | Pts |

article:
FTX

FTX was a cryptocurrency derivatives exchange that was founded in 2019 by Sam Bankman-Fried and Gary Wang. The exchange was headquartered in the Bahamas and was known for its high trading volumes and innovative products. However, in November 2022, FTX faced a major crisis that led to its bankruptcy and had far-reaching consequences for the cryptocurrency market.

#History

FTX was founded in 2019 by Sam Bankman-Fried and Gary Wang, two former traders at Jane Street, a global trading firm. The exchange was initially focused on offering cryptocurrency derivatives, including futures and options. FTX quickly gained popularity among traders due to its high liquidity, low fees, and innovative products.

In 2020, FTX raised $8 million in a seed funding round from investors such as Binance Labs, the venture arm of the cryptocurrency exchange Binance. The exchange continued to grow rapidly, and by 2021, it had become one of the largest cryptocurrency derivatives exchanges in the world.

In addition to its exchange business, FTX also operated a trading firm called Alameda Research, which was founded by Sam Bankman-Fried in 2017. Alameda was a quantitative trading firm that used advanced algorithms to trade cryptocurrencies and other assets.

#November 2022 crisis and bankruptcy

##Background: FTX and Alameda, Binance, and CoinDesk report

In the months leading up to the crisis, FTX and its affiliated trading firm Alameda Research had been facing financial difficulties. According to reports, Alameda had been using FTX customer funds to trade and had amassed significant losses.

On November 2, 2022, a report by CoinDesk revealed that a significant portion of Alameda's balance sheet was composed of FTX's native token, FTT. This raised concerns about the solvency of Alameda and the potential risks to FTX customers.

##Crisis begins: Binance FTT sale, sell-off, and withdrawn rescue bid

On November 6, 2022, Binance, a major cryptocurrency exchange and investor in FTX, announced that it would be selling its entire stake in FTT. This move was seen as a major blow to FTX, as Binance was one of its largest investors.

Following Binance's announcement, the price of FTT began to plummet, leading to a sell-off in the token. FTX customers began to withdraw their funds from the exchange, leading to a liquidity crisis.

On November 8, 2022, Binance announced that it had reached a non-binding agreement to acquire FTX, pending due diligence. However, just hours later, Binance withdrew its bid, citing concerns about FTX's financial condition.

##Bankruptcy and unauthorized transactions

On November 11, 2022, FTX filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in the United States. The exchange announced that it would be ceasing all trading operations and would be conducting an orderly wind-down of its business.

In the days following the bankruptcy filing, it was revealed that FTX had been the victim of a major hack, with unauthorized transactions totaling hundreds of millions of dollars. The hack was believed to have been carried out by an insider, and it was unclear whether the perpetrator was still at large.

##Widening impact and contagion fears

The collapse of FTX sent shockwaves through the cryptocurrency market, with many traders and investors facing significant losses. The price of Bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies plummeted, and many other cryptocurrency exchanges and firms faced liquidity crises.

There were fears of a contagion effect, with many investors worried that the collapse of FTX could lead to a broader crisis in the cryptocurrency market.

##Responses and effects

###Effects on investors

The collapse of FTX had a devastating impact on many investors, with many facing significant losses. Some investors had invested their life savings in FTX, and the collapse of the exchange left them financially ruined.

###Effects on other cryptocurrency firms and cryptocurrency markets

The collapse of FTX had a significant impact on other cryptocurrency firms and markets. Many firms faced liquidity crises, and some were forced to cease operations.

The price of Bitcoin and other major cryptocurrencies plummeted, and many investors lost confidence in the cryptocurrency market.

###Responses and commentary

The collapse of FTX was met with widespread criticism and commentary from the cryptocurrency community. Many commentators criticized the lack of regulation and oversight in the cryptocurrency market, and called for greater transparency and accountability.

Some commentators also criticized the role of Binance and other major cryptocurrency exchanges in the collapse of FTX, suggesting that they had played a role in exacerbating the crisis.

#Legal process

Following the collapse of FTX, the exchange's founder Sam Bankman-Fried was the subject of a number of lawsuits and regulatory investigations. In December 2022, Bankman-Fried was arrested in the Bahamas and extradited to the United States, where he faced charges of wire fraud and securities fraud.

The collapse of FTX also led to a number of regulatory investigations, with many governments and regulatory bodies launching probes into the exchange's activities.

#Sponsorships

FTX had been a major sponsor of a number of high-profile events and organizations, including the Miami Heat basketball team and the Mercedes-AMG Petronas Formula One team. Following the collapse of the exchange, many of these sponsorships were terminated.

2022–23 European windstorm season

The 2022–23 European windstorm season was the fifth instance of seasonal European windstorm naming in Europe. The season officially started on October 1, 2022, and ended on March 31, 2023. This season saw a moderate number of significant storms, with several countries affected by strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas.

# Background and naming

## Definitions and naming conventions

The European windstorm season is a period of the year when certain regions in Europe are prone to experiencing severe windstorms. These storms can bring strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas, leading to disruptions and damage. The season is typically defined as the period between October 1 and March 31.

## Western Group (United Kingdom, Ireland and the Netherlands)

The Western Group consists of the United Kingdom, Ireland, and the Netherlands. This region is prone to experiencing strong winds and heavy rainfall due to its proximity to the Atlantic Ocean. The UK Met Office, Met Éireann, and the Royal Netherlands Meteorological Institute (KNMI) are responsible for naming storms in this region.

## South-western Group (France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium and Luxembourg)

The South-western Group includes France, Spain, Portugal, Belgium, and Luxembourg. This region is susceptible to experiencing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas due to its location near the Atlantic Ocean and the Mediterranean Sea. Météo-France, the Spanish Meteorological Agency (AEMET), the Portuguese Institute for the Sea and Atmosphere (IPMA), the Royal Meteorological Institute of Belgium (RMI), and the Luxembourg Institute of Meteorology and Hydrology (IMH) are responsible for naming storms in this region.

## Southeastern Mediterranean Group (Greece, Israel and Cyprus)

The Southeastern Mediterranean Group comprises Greece, Israel, and Cyprus. This region is prone to experiencing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas due to its location in the southeastern Mediterranean. The Hellenic National Meteorological Service (HNMS), the Israel Meteorological Service (IMS), and the Cyprus Meteorological Service (CMS) are responsible for naming storms in this region.

## Central Mediterranean Group (Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, North Macedonia and Malta)

The Central Mediterranean Group includes Italy, Slovenia, Croatia, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, North Macedonia, and Malta. This region is susceptible to experiencing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas due to its location in the central Mediterranean. The Italian Meteorological Service (ARPA-SIM), the Slovenian Environment Agency (ARSO), the Croatian Meteorological and Hydrological Service (DHMZ), the Meteorological Institute of Bosnia & Herzegovina (FHMZ), the Hydrological and Meteorological Service of Montenegro (HMS), the Macedonian Meteorological Institute (MMS), and the Malta Meteorological Office (MMO) are responsible for naming storms in this region.

## Northern Group (Denmark, Norway and Sweden)

The Northern Group consists of Denmark, Norway, and Sweden. This region is prone to experiencing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas due to its location near the North Sea and the Baltic Sea. The Danish Meteorological Institute (DMI), the Norwegian Meteorological Institute (MET Norway), and the Swedish Meteorological and Hydrological Institute (SMHI) are responsible for naming storms in this region.

## Central & Southern Group (Germany, Switzerland, Liechtenstein and Austria)

The Central & Southern Group includes Germany, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, and Austria. This region is susceptible to experiencing strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas due to its location in the central and southern parts of Europe. The German Weather Service (DWD), the Swiss Federal Office of Meteorology and Climatology (MeteoSwiss), the Liechtenstein National Meteorological Service (LNM), and the Central Institute for Meteorology and Geodynamics (ZAMG) are responsible for naming storms in this region.

## Ex-Atlantic Hurricane

Ex-Atlantic hurricanes can bring strong winds, heavy rainfall, and rough seas to Europe, particularly the western and northern regions. These storms are typically named by the National Hurricane Center (NHC) and are often referred to as ex-hurricanes when they transition into extratropical cyclones.

article:
2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season is an ongoing event in the annual cycle of tropical cyclone formation. The season began on July 1, 2022, and will end on June 30, 2023. This season has seen a significant number of tropical cyclones, some of which have had a substantial impact on the region.

# Seasonal forecasts

Prior to the start of the season, several national meteorological agencies and scientific institutions issued forecasts predicting the number of tropical cyclones that would form in the South-West Indian Ocean. The Mauritius Meteorological Services, which is responsible for monitoring and predicting tropical cyclones in the region, predicted that the season would be near-average in terms of the number of systems that would form.

# Seasonal summary

As of March 1, 2023, a total of 11 tropical cyclones have formed in the South-West Indian Ocean. Of these, 5 have reached tropical cyclone strength, while 2 have reached intense tropical cyclone strength. The most intense cyclone of the season so far has been Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy, which reached a peak intensity of 230 km/h (145 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 925 hPa (27.32 inHg).

## Systems

### Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley

Moderate Tropical Storm Ashley was the first tropical cyclone of the season. It formed on July 10, 2022, in the eastern part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,000 km (620 miles) east of the coast of Madagascar. Ashley moved in a westerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 85 km/h (53 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 995 hPa (29.38 inHg) before dissipating on July 14, 2022.

### Moderate Tropical Storm Balita

Moderate Tropical Storm Balita formed on August 5, 2022, in the northwestern part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 500 km (310 miles) north of the coast of Mozambique. Balita moved in a southerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 80 km/h (50 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 1,000 hPa (29.53 inHg) before dissipating on August 9, 2022.

### Tropical Depression 03

Tropical Depression 03 formed on September 15, 2022, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,500 km (930 miles) east of the coast of Madagascar. The system moved in a westerly direction, but failed to strengthen further, dissipating on September 17, 2022.

### Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Darian formed on October 20, 2022, in the eastern part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,200 km (750 miles) east of the coast of Madagascar. Darian moved in a westerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 220 km/h (137 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 935 hPa (27.61 inHg) before dissipating on October 25, 2022.

### Tropical Cyclone Cheneso

Tropical Cyclone Cheneso formed on January 18, 2023, in the northwestern part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 500 km (310 miles) north of the coast of Mozambique. Cheneso moved in a southerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 100 km/h (62 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 995 hPa (29.38 inHg) before making landfall in Mozambique on January 19, 2023.

### Tropical Cyclone Dingani

Tropical Cyclone Dingani formed on February 10, 2023, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,000 km (620 miles) east of the coast of Madagascar. Dingani moved in a westerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 90 km/h (56 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 1,000 hPa (29.53 inHg) before dissipating on February 13, 2023.

### Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy

Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy formed on February 5, 2023, in the eastern part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,500 km (930 miles) east of the coast of Madagascar. Freddy moved in a westerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 230 km/h (145 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 925 hPa (27.32 inHg) before dissipating on February 14, 2023.

### Tropical Cyclone Enala

Tropical Cyclone Enala formed on March 1, 2023, in the northwestern part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 500 km (310 miles) north of the coast of Mozambique. Enala moved in a southerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 80 km/h (50 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 1,005 hPa (29.68 inHg) before dissipating on March 4, 2023.

### Moderate Tropical Storm 09

Moderate Tropical Storm 09 formed on March 10, 2023, in the central part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,000 km (620 miles) east of the coast of Madagascar. The system moved in a westerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 75 km/h (47 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 1,010 hPa (29.83 inHg) before dissipating on March 12, 2023.

### Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien

Intense Tropical Cyclone Fabien formed on March 15, 2023, in the eastern part of the South-West Indian Ocean, approximately 1,200 km (750 miles) east of the coast of Madagascar. Fabien moved in a westerly direction, reaching a peak intensity of 200 km/h (124 mph) and a minimum central pressure of 945 hPa (27.91 inHg) before dissipating on March 19, 2023.

# Storm names

The names of tropical cyclones in the South-West Indian Ocean are assigned from a list of names that has been agreed upon by the member countries of the Regional Specialized Meteorological Centre (RSMC) La Réunion. The list of names is used in a cyclical manner, with the names of the most destructive cyclones being retired from the list.

# Season effects

The 2022–23 South-West Indian Ocean cyclone season has had a significant impact on the region, with several tropical cyclones causing damage and loss of life. The most destructive cyclone of the season so far has been Very Intense Tropical Cyclone Freddy, which caused widespread damage and flooding in Madagascar and Mozambique.

article:
Ronald Reagan
================

Ronald Wilson Reagan (February 6, 1911 – June 5, 2004) was the 40th President of the United States, serving from 1981 to 1989. Prior to his presidency, he was a Hollywood actor and served as the 33rd Governor of California from 1967 to 1975. Reagan is often regarded as one of the most influential figures of the 20th century, known for his conservative policies, charismatic leadership, and role in ending the Cold War.

Early Life
-----------

Ronald Reagan was born on February 6, 1911, in Tampico, Illinois, to John Edward Reagan and Nelle Clyde Wilson Reagan. He was the younger of two sons, with an older brother, Neil. Reagan's father was a salesman and a sports enthusiast who instilled in his sons a love for sports and the outdoors. The family moved frequently during Reagan's childhood, eventually settling in Dixon, Illinois, where he attended high school.

Entertainment Career
---------------------

### Radio and Film

Reagan began his career in entertainment as a radio sports announcer in Des Moines, Iowa, in 1932. He later moved to California, where he signed a seven-year contract with Warner Bros. studios in 1937. Over the next several years, Reagan appeared in over 50 films, mostly in supporting roles. Some of his notable films include "Knute Rockne, All American" (1940) and "Santa Fe Trail" (1940).

### Military Service

During World War II, Reagan enlisted in the U.S. Army Reserve in 1937 and was called to active duty in 1942. He served as a liaison officer and was assigned to the Army Air Forces, where he produced training films and was eventually promoted to captain. Reagan was honorably discharged in 1945.

### Screen Actors Guild Presidency

Reagan became involved in the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) in the 1940s and was elected president of the guild in 1947. He served as president until 1952 and again from 1959 to 1960. During his tenure, Reagan played a key role in negotiating contracts and advocating for actors' rights.

### Marriages and Children

Reagan married actress Jane Wyman in 1940, and they had two children, Maureen and Michael. The couple divorced in 1948. In 1952, Reagan married actress Nancy Davis, with whom he had two children, Patricia and Ronald Jr.

### Television

Reagan began transitioning to television in the 1950s, hosting several shows, including "General Electric Theater" (1954-1962) and "Death Valley Days" (1964-1965).

Early Political Activities
---------------------------

### 1966 California Gubernatorial Election

Reagan's entry into politics began in 1966, when he ran for Governor of California. He won the Republican primary and went on to defeat incumbent Governor Pat Brown in the general election.

California Governorship (1967-1975)
-----------------------------------

Reagan served as Governor of California from 1967 to 1975. During his tenure, he implemented several conservative policies, including tax cuts and reductions in government spending. He also signed several notable bills, including a bill to restrict abortion and a bill to allow the state to take control of the University of California system.

Seeking the Presidency (1975-1981)
---------------------------------

### 1976 Republican Primaries

Reagan ran for the Republican presidential nomination in 1976, but lost to incumbent President Gerald Ford. He ran again in 1980, this time winning the nomination and going on to defeat Democratic incumbent Jimmy Carter in the general election.

### 1980 Election

Reagan's 1980 campaign focused on several key issues, including tax cuts, reductions in government spending, and a strong national defense. He also campaigned on a platform of social conservatism, including opposition to abortion and support for prayer in public schools.

Presidency (1981-1989)
----------------------

### First Inauguration

Reagan's first inauguration took place on January 20, 1981. In his inaugural address, he famously declared that "government is not the solution to our problem; government is the problem."

### "Reaganomics" and the Economy

Reagan's economic policies, known as "Reaganomics," focused on reducing government spending, cutting taxes, and deregulating industries. The policies included:

#### Taxation

Reagan signed the Economic Recovery Tax Act (ERTA) in 1981, which reduced tax rates across the board. He also signed the Tax Reform Act of 1986, which eliminated many tax loopholes and deductions.

#### Inflation and Unemployment

Reagan's policies aimed to reduce inflation and unemployment. He appointed conservative Federal Reserve Chairman Paul Volcker, who implemented tight monetary policies to combat inflation. Unemployment rates declined from 7.5% in 1980 to 5.3% in 1989.

#### Government Spending

Reagan reduced government spending as a percentage of GDP, from 22.2% in 1980 to 20.6% in 1989. However, total government spending still increased during his presidency.

#### Deregulation

Reagan implemented several deregulation policies, including the deregulation of the airline and trucking industries. He also signed the Gramm-Leach-Bliley Act, which repealed parts of the Glass-Steagall Act and allowed banks to engage in securities trading.

#### Deficits

Despite his efforts to reduce government spending, Reagan's policies led to significant budget deficits. The national debt increased from $994 billion in 1980 to $2.1 trillion in 1989.

### Assassination Attempt

On March 30, 1981, Reagan was shot by John Hinckley Jr. outside the Washington Hilton Hotel. Reagan suffered serious injuries, including a punctured lung and internal bleeding. He made a remarkable recovery and returned to work within several weeks.

### Supreme Court Appointments

Reagan appointed two Supreme Court justices during his presidency: Sandra Day O'Connor in 1981 and Antonin Scalia in 1986.

### Public Sector Labor Union Fights

Reagan was a strong opponent of public sector labor unions. In 1981, he fired over 11,000 air traffic controllers who went on strike, citing national security concerns.

### Civil Rights

Reagan's administration was criticized for its handling of civil rights issues. He opposed the extension of the Voting Rights Act and vetoed the Civil Rights Act of 1987.

### War on Drugs

Reagan launched the "War on Drugs" in 1982, which aimed to reduce drug use and trafficking. The campaign included increased funding for law enforcement and tougher sentencing laws.

### Escalation of the Cold War

Reagan's presidency saw a significant escalation of the Cold War. He increased military spending and implemented several policies aimed at countering Soviet influence, including the deployment of intermediate-range missiles in Europe.

### Invasion of Grenada

In 1983, Reagan authorized the invasion of Grenada, a small island nation in the Caribbean, citing concerns about Soviet influence and the safety of American medical students.

### 1984 Election

Reagan ran for re-election in 1984, defeating Democratic challenger Walter Mondale in a landslide.

### Response to the AIDS Epidemic

Reagan's administration was criticized for its slow response to the AIDS epidemic. He did not publicly mention the disease until 1985, and funding for AIDS research and treatment was limited.

### Addressing Apartheid

Reagan's administration was criticized for its handling of apartheid in South Africa. He vetoed the Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act in 1986, which aimed to impose sanctions on the South African government.

### Libya Bombing

In 1986, Reagan authorized the bombing of Libya, citing concerns about terrorism and Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi's support for anti-American groups.

### Iran-Contra Affair

The Iran-Contra affair, which involved the sale of arms to Iran and the use of funds to support anti-Sandinista rebels in Nicaragua, led to significant controversy and criticism of Reagan's administration.

### The USS Stark Incident

In 1987, the USS Stark was attacked by an Iraqi warplane, killing 37 American sailors. The incident highlighted the risks of American involvement in the Iran-Iraq War.

### Soviet Decline and Thaw in Relations

Reagan's presidency saw significant decline in Soviet influence and a thaw in relations between the United States and the Soviet Union. He met with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev several times, including at the Geneva Summit in 1985 and the Reykjavik Summit in 1986.

Post-Presidency (1989-2004)
-------------------------

### Support for Brady Bill

After leaving office, Reagan supported the Brady Handgun Violence Prevention Act, which aimed to reduce gun violence.

### Alzheimer's Disease

Reagan was diagnosed with Alzheimer's disease in 1994. He died on June 5, 2004, at the age of 93.

### Death and Funeral

Reagan's funeral was held on June 11, 2004, and was attended by world leaders and dignitaries.

Legacy
--------

### Historical Reputation

Reagan's legacy is complex and multifaceted. He is remembered as a strong leader who helped to end the Cold War and implement conservative policies. However, his administration was also criticized for its handling of civil rights and social issues.

### Political Influence

Reagan's influence on American politics is significant. He helped to shift the Republican Party to the right and paved the way for future conservative leaders.

Notes
-----

References
----------

External Links
---------------

* The Washington Post: Ronald Reagan

Siege of Mariupol

The Siege of Mariupol was a prolonged military confrontation between Ukrainian and Russian forces in the city of Mariupol, Ukraine, during the 2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine. The siege began on February 24, 2022, and lasted for over two months, resulting in significant damage to the city and its infrastructure, as well as a large number of civilian and military casualties.

#Background

Mariupol, a strategic port city in eastern Ukraine, has been a key location in the conflict between Ukraine and Russian-backed separatists since 2014. The city is situated in the Donetsk region, which has been the site of ongoing fighting between Ukrainian government forces and Russian-backed separatists. In the months leading up to the 2022 invasion, tensions between Ukraine and Russia escalated, with Russia amassing troops along the border and launching a series of cyberattacks against Ukrainian targets.

2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts

The 2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts was held from February 17 to 26, 2023, at the Sandman Centre in Kamloops, British Columbia. The tournament was the 41st edition of the Scotties Tournament of Hearts, the annual women's curling championship of Canada.

# Teams

The 2023 Scotties Tournament of Hearts featured 18 teams, including 10 provincial and territorial champions, three wild card teams, and five teams that qualified through the Canadian Team Ranking System (CTRS).

article:
Francis Drake

Sir Francis Drake was an English sea captain, explorer, and privateer who played a significant role in the defeat of the Spanish Armada and was the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe. Born in 1540 in Tavistock, Devon, England, Drake rose to prominence during the Elizabethan era and became a celebrated figure in English history.

# Birth and early years

Francis Drake was born in 1540 in Tavistock, Devon, England, to Edmund Drake and Mary Mylwaye. His early life is not well documented, but it is believed that he grew up in a Protestant family and received a basic education. In his youth, Drake was apprenticed to a merchant shipowner and began his career at sea.

# Early career at sea

Drake's early career at sea was marked by involvement in the slave trade and privateering expeditions against Spanish ships.

## Slave trade

In the 1560s, Drake was involved in the slave trade, transporting enslaved Africans to the Americas. This experience gave him knowledge of the Caribbean and its trade routes, which would later benefit him in his pirating and privateering expeditions.

## Expedition of 1572–1573

In 1572, Drake embarked on an expedition to the Caribbean, where he raided Spanish ships and colonies. This expedition was likely sponsored by a group of English investors who hoped to profit from the capture of Spanish vessels and cargo.

## Rathlin Island massacre

In 1575, Drake was involved in the Rathlin Island massacre, in which a group of English and Scottish soldiers attacked and killed hundreds of Scottish and Irish civilians who were hiding on the island. Drake's role in the massacre is not well documented, but it is believed that he was present during the attack.

# Circumnavigation (1577–1580)

Drake's most famous expedition was his circumnavigation of the globe, which took place from 1577 to 1580.

## Execution of Thomas Doughty

Before setting sail, Drake had Thomas Doughty, a fellow Englishman, executed for mutiny. Doughty had been accused of plotting against Drake and was put on trial by a council of Drake's officers. The execution was seen as a necessary measure to maintain discipline and order on the voyage.

## Entering the Pacific (1578)

In 1578, Drake sailed through the Strait of Magellan at the tip of South America and entered the Pacific Ocean. This was a significant achievement, as it marked the first time an English ship had navigated the strait.

## Raids on Spanish American west coast

Once in the Pacific, Drake raided Spanish ships and colonies along the west coast of South America. He captured several vessels and took control of the Spanish ship Nuestra Señora de la Victoria, which he later used as his flagship.

## Coast of California: Nova Albion (1579)

In 1579, Drake landed on the coast of California, which he claimed for England and named Nova Albion. This claim was later disputed by the Spanish, who argued that the area was part of their colonial territory.

## Across the Pacific and around Africa

After leaving California, Drake sailed across the Pacific and around Africa, returning to England in 1580. This voyage marked the first time an English ship had circumnavigated the globe.

## Return to Plymouth (1580)

Drake returned to Plymouth, England, in 1580, where he was greeted as a hero. He brought back a large quantity of gold, silver, and other treasures, which he had captured during his raids on Spanish ships and colonies.

## Knighthood and arms

In 1581, Drake was knighted by Queen Elizabeth I for his services to the English crown. He was also granted a coat of arms, which featured a wyvern (a mythical creature) and the motto "Sic Parvis Magna" ("Greatness from small beginnings").

# Political career

Drake's success at sea and his popularity with the English public made him a natural candidate for politics. He served as a member of Parliament for Plymouth and later for Bossiney, Cornwall.

# Great Expedition to America

In 1585, Drake was appointed commander of a fleet that was sent to the Americas to attack Spanish colonies and ships. This expedition was known as the Great Expedition to America.

# Conflict with the Spanish Armada

In 1588, Drake played a key role in the defeat of the Spanish Armada, a fleet of ships that was sent by King Philip II of Spain to invade England.

## Cádiz raid

In 1587, Drake led a raid on the Spanish port of Cádiz, where he sank several ships and disrupted the Spanish naval preparations for the Armada.

## Defeat of the Spanish Armada

In 1588, the Spanish Armada was defeated by a combination of bad weather, poor planning, and the English navy. Drake played a key role in the battle, commanding a fleet of ships that attacked the Spanish vessels.

## English Armada

In 1589, Drake was appointed commander of a fleet that was sent to Spain to attack the Spanish navy and disrupt their trade routes. This expedition was known as the English Armada.

# Defeats and death

Drake's later years were marked by a series of defeats and setbacks. He was defeated by the Spanish at the Battle of Las Palmas in 1595 and died of dysentery in 1596, while on a voyage to the Caribbean.

# Family and heritage

Drake married twice, first to Mary Newman and then to Elizabeth Sydenham. He had no children, but his legacy lived on through his family and his descendants.

# Legacy and honours

Drake's legacy is still celebrated today. He is remembered as a hero of the English navy and a pioneer of exploration and privateering.

## Geographical names

Drake's name is commemorated in several geographical locations, including Drake's Bay in California, Drake's Passage at the tip of South America, and the Drake Strait in the Antarctic.

article:
2022 Shpageeza Cricket League
==========================

The 2022 Shpageeza Cricket League was the eighth edition of the Shpageeza Cricket League, a professional Twenty20 cricket league in Afghanistan. The tournament was held from July 18 to August 5, 2022, and featured eight teams competing in a round-robin format, followed by a knockout stage.

Squads
------

The eight teams that participated in the tournament were:

* Amo Sharks
* Bost Defenders
* Kabul Eagles
* Hindukush Stars
* MAK Speen Ghar Region
* Pamir Zalmi
* Speen Ghar Tigers
* Valley Boys

Each team had a squad of 18 players, with a mix of local and international cricketers. The teams were allowed to make changes to their squads during the tournament.

Standings
---------

### Points table

The points table was used to determine the top four teams that qualified for the knockout stage. The teams were ranked based on the number of points they earned during the group stage, with two points awarded for a win and one point for a no-result or abandoned match.

| Team | Played | Won | Lost | No Result | Points |
| --- | --- | --- | --- | --- | --- |
| Kabul Eagles | 7 | 6 | 1 | 0 | 12 |
| MAK Speen Ghar Region | 7 | 5 | 2 | 0 | 10 |
| Bost Defenders | 7 | 4 | 3 | 0 | 8 |
| Pamir Zalmi | 7 | 3 | 4 | 0 | 6 |
| Amo Sharks | 7 | 3 | 4 | 0 | 6 |
| Speen Ghar Tigers | 7 | 2 | 5 | 0 | 4 |
| Valley Boys | 7 | 2 | 5 | 0 | 4 |
| Hindukush Stars | 7 | 1 | 6 | 0 | 2 |

Fixtures
--------

The group stage of the tournament consisted of 28 matches, with each team playing seven matches against the other teams. The matches were played at the Kabul International Cricket Stadium and the Alokozay Kabul International Cricket Ground.

The fixtures were as follows:

* July 18: Kabul Eagles vs. Hindukush Stars
* July 18: MAK Speen Ghar Region vs. Amo Sharks
* July 19: Bost Defenders vs. Speen Ghar Tigers
* July 19: Pamir Zalmi vs. Valley Boys
* July 20: Kabul Eagles vs. MAK Speen Ghar Region
* July 20: Hindukush Stars vs. Amo Sharks
* July 21: Bost Defenders vs. Pamir Zalmi
* July 21: Speen Ghar Tigers vs. Valley Boys
* July 22: Kabul Eagles vs. Bost Defenders
* July 22: MAK Speen Ghar Region vs. Speen Ghar Tigers
* July 23: Hindukush Stars vs. Pamir Zalmi
* July 23: Amo Sharks vs. Valley Boys
* July 24: Kabul Eagles vs. Speen Ghar Tigers
* July 24: MAK Speen Ghar Region vs. Pamir Zalmi
* July 25: Bost Defenders vs. Amo Sharks
* July 25: Hindukush Stars vs. Valley Boys
* July 26: Kabul Eagles vs. Pamir Zalmi
* July 26: MAK Speen Ghar Region vs. Bost Defenders
* July 27: Speen Ghar Tigers vs. Hindukush Stars
* July 27: Valley Boys vs. Amo Sharks
* July 28: Kabul Eagles vs. Amo Sharks
* July 28: MAK Speen Ghar Region vs. Hindukush Stars
* July 29: Bost Defenders vs. Valley Boys
* July 29: Pamir Zalmi vs. Speen Ghar Tigers

Knockout stage
-------------

The knockout stage consisted of four matches: two Qualifier matches, an Eliminator match, and the Final.

### Qualifier 1

The first Qualifier match was played between the top two teams in the points table, Kabul Eagles and MAK Speen Ghar Region. The match was played on August 1, 2022, at the Kabul International Cricket Stadium.

Kabul Eagles won the toss and elected to bat first. They scored 181 runs in 20 overs, with opener Ibrahim Zadran scoring a half-century. MAK Speen Ghar Region responded with 178 runs in 20 overs, losing two wickets. Kabul Eagles won the match by three runs.

### Eliminator

The Eliminator match was played between the third-placed team, Bost Defenders, and the fourth-placed team, Pamir Zalmi. The match was played on August 1, 2022, at the Alokozay Kabul International Cricket Ground.

Pamir Zalmi won the toss and elected to bat first. They scored 149 runs in 20 overs, with opener Usman Ghani scoring a half-century. Bost Defenders responded with 151 runs in 18.3 overs, winning the match by six wickets.

### Qualifier 2

The second Qualifier match was played between MAK Speen Ghar Region and Bost Defenders. The match was played on August 3, 2022, at the Kabul International Cricket Stadium.

Bost Defenders won the toss and elected to bat first. They scored 158 runs in 20 overs, with opener Fazal Niazai scoring a half-century. MAK Speen Ghar Region responded with 159 runs in 19.2 overs, winning the match by two wickets.

### Final

The Final match was played between Kabul Eagles and MAK Speen Ghar Region. The match was played on August 5, 2022, at the Kabul International Cricket Stadium.

Kabul Eagles won the toss and elected to bat first. They scored 193 runs in 20 overs, with opener Ibrahim Zadran scoring a half-century. MAK Speen Ghar Region responded with 194 runs in 19.3 overs, winning the match by six wickets.

MAK Speen Ghar Region won the 2022 Shpageeza Cricket League, defeating Kabul Eagles in the Final.

article:
Ice Spice

Ice Spice is an American rapper, singer, and songwriter from the Bronx, New York. She rose to fame in 2022 with her debut single "Munch (Feelin' U)" and has since become one of the most promising young artists in the hip-hop industry.

#Early life and education

Ice Spice was born Isis Naija Gaston on January 23, 2000, in the Bronx, New York. She grew up in a low-income household with her mother, a former corrections officer, and her younger brother. Spice's early life was marked by struggles, including experiencing poverty and witnessing violence in her neighborhood. Despite these challenges, she found solace in music, particularly hip-hop, which became a source of inspiration and escapism.

Spice attended the State University of New York at Purchase, where she studied dance and began to develop her rapping skills. However, she dropped out of college after her freshman year to focus on her music career.

#Career

##2021–2022: Career beginnings

Ice Spice began her music career in 2021, releasing her debut single "Bully Freestyle" on SoundCloud. The song gained moderate attention online, but it was her follow-up single "Munch (Feelin' U)" that truly launched her career. Released in August 2022, "Munch" became a viral hit, with its catchy hook and Spice's confident, playful flow resonating with listeners.

The success of "Munch" led to Spice signing with Capitol Records and 10K Projects, a record label co-founded by music industry executive Elliot Grainge. She released her debut EP, "Like..?", in January 2023, which featured the hit singles "Gangsta Boo" and "In Ha Mood".

##2023–present: Breakthrough with Like…?

Like…? marked a significant breakthrough for Ice Spice, establishing her as a rising star in the hip-hop world. The EP debuted at number 15 on the US Billboard 200 chart and featured collaborations with artists such as Lil Tjay and Fivio Foreign.

The success of Like…? led to Spice embarking on her first headlining tour, the "Like…? Tour", which kicked off in March 2023. She also made her debut on late-night television, performing on The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon in April 2023.

#Artistry

##Musical and lyrical style

Ice Spice's music is characterized by her confident, playful flow and her ability to blend hip-hop with elements of drill and pop. Her lyrics often focus on themes of self-empowerment, relationships, and street life, showcasing her unique perspective as a young woman from the Bronx.

Spice's music is also notable for its catchy, melodic hooks, which have become a hallmark of her style. Her songs often feature a mix of heavy, distorted basslines and more atmospheric, ambient production, creating a distinctive sound that sets her apart from other artists.

##Influences

Ice Spice has cited a range of influences on her music, including hip-hop legends such as Lil' Kim and Missy Elliott, as well as contemporary artists like Nicki Minaj and Megan Thee Stallion. She has also mentioned being influenced by pop and R&B, citing artists such as Lady Gaga and The Weeknd as inspirations.

#Personal life

##Feuds & controversies

Ice Spice has been involved in several high-profile feuds and controversies throughout her career. In 2022, she was involved in a public feud with fellow rapper, Lil Tjay, which played out on social media. The two artists have since squashed their beef and collaborated on music.

Spice has also faced criticism for her lyrics, which some have accused of promoting violence and misogyny. However, she has maintained that her music is a reflection of her experiences and the world around her, and that she is simply telling her story.

#Tours

* Like…? Tour (2023)

##Supporting

* None

* None

#References

* None

article:
Coco Lee

Coco Lee (January 17, 1975 – July 5, 2023) was a Hong Kong-born American singer, songwriter, record producer, and actress. She was one of the most successful and influential Chinese pop artists of all time, known for her powerful vocals, energetic live performances, and iconic music videos.

#Early life

Coco Lee was born on January 17, 1975, in Hong Kong to a Chinese father and a Filipino mother. She grew up in a musical family and began singing at a young age. Lee's family moved to San Francisco, California, when she was three years old, and she spent most of her childhood in the United States. She attended high school in California and began performing in local talent shows and competitions.

#Career

##Career beginnings and Sony Music: 1993–1998

Lee's music career began in 1993 when she was discovered by a talent scout while performing at a karaoke bar in San Francisco. She was signed to Sony Music Entertainment and released her debut album, "Love from Now On," in 1994. The album was a moderate success, but it was her second album, "Promise," released in 1995, that brought her widespread recognition in Asia.

##International collaborations and English debut: 1998–2005

In 1998, Lee collaborated with international artists such as Teddy Riley and Keith Martin on her album "Di Da Di." The album's lead single, "Do You Want My Love," became a hit in Asia and marked Lee's transition to a more pop-oriented sound. In 1999, Lee released her English debut album, "Just No Other Way," which included the hit single "Can't Get Over." The album was a commercial success, and Lee became the first Chinese artist to have an English album certified platinum in Asia.

##Second English album and Warner Music: 2005–2011

In 2005, Lee signed with Warner Music Group and released her second English album, "Exposed." The album's lead single, "No Doubt," became a hit in Asia, and the album itself was certified platinum in several countries. Lee continued to release successful albums and singles throughout the late 2000s, including "1111" and "East to West."

##New album and final projects before death: 2011–2023

In 2011, Lee released her album "Illuminate," which included the hit single "Party Time." Lee continued to perform and record music throughout the 2010s, releasing several singles and collaborating with other artists. In 2016, Lee released her album "Mirror," which marked her 20th anniversary in the music industry.

#Personal life

Lee was known for her private and low-key personal life. She was married to Bruce Rockowitz, an American businessman, from 2011 until her death in 2023.

#Health issues

Lee had been open about her struggles with depression and anxiety throughout her career. In 2019, she revealed that she had been diagnosed with bipolar disorder and had been undergoing treatment.

#Death

Lee passed away on July 5, 2023, at the age of 48. Her death was met with an outpouring of tributes and condolences from fans and fellow artists around the world.

##Services and tributes

A private funeral service was held for Lee in Hong Kong, attended by her family, friends, and fellow artists. A public memorial service was also held in Hong Kong, where fans and well-wishers paid their respects to Lee.

##Aftermath

###Leaked clips and Sing! China

In the aftermath of Lee's death, several leaked clips of her unreleased music and footage from her final days were circulated online. Lee's team and family were quick to condemn the leaks, calling them "disrespectful" and " hurtful." The incident sparked a wider conversation about the ethics of sharing private and unreleased content after an artist's death.

Lee's team also announced that she had been working on a new album at the time of her death, which would be released posthumously. The album, titled "Forever Coco," was released in 2024 to critical acclaim and commercial success.

#Legacy

Coco Lee's legacy as a trailblazing and influential Chinese pop artist continues to be felt around the world. Her music and message of hope and empowerment have inspired countless fans and artists, and her impact on the music industry will be remembered for generations to come.

#Philanthropy

Lee was a dedicated philanthropist and supporter of several charitable causes throughout her career. She worked closely with organizations such as the Red Cross and UNICEF, and was a vocal advocate for LGBTQ+ rights and awareness.

#Artistry

Lee was known for her powerful vocals, energetic live performances, and iconic music videos. She was a true artist and innovator, always pushing the boundaries of what was possible in the music industry.

article:
2022 Ontario General Election

The 2022 Ontario general election was held on June 2, 2022, to elect the 124 members of the Legislative Assembly of Ontario, Canada. The election was called on May 4, 2022, by Lieutenant Governor of Ontario Elizabeth Dowdeswell, on the advice of Premier Doug Ford.

# Background

The 2018 Ontario general election resulted in a Progressive Conservative (PC) majority government, with Doug Ford as the premier. The PC party won 76 seats, while the New Democratic Party (NDP) won 40 seats, the Liberal Party won 7 seats, and the Green Party won 1 seat. The 2022 election was the first time that the PCs would face the electorate since their 2018 victory.

# Timeline

## 2018

The 2018 Ontario general election was held on June 7, 2018. The election resulted in a PC majority government, with Doug Ford as the premier.

## 2020

In 2020, the COVID-19 pandemic hit Ontario, and the government implemented various measures to combat the spread of the virus. The government also introduced several pieces of legislation, including the COVID-19 Economic Recovery Act, which aimed to support businesses and individuals affected by the pandemic.

## 2021

In 2021, the government introduced several pieces of legislation, including the Protecting Ontario Elections Act, which aimed to increase transparency and accountability in election finance. The government also introduced the Ontario Plan to Build, which aimed to support the construction of new homes and infrastructure.

## 2022

On May 4, 2022, Lieutenant Governor Elizabeth Dowdeswell dissolved the 42nd Parliament and called a general election for June 2, 2022. The election campaign began, with the PCs, NDP, Liberals, and Greens launching their campaigns and releasing their platforms.

# Campaign Period

## Candidates not standing for reelection

Several members of the Legislative Assembly announced that they would not be standing for reelection in 2022. These included PC members Norm Miller and Laurie Scott, NDP member Judith Monteith-Farrell, and Liberal member Mitzie Hunter.

## Party slogans

The party slogans for the 2022 election were:

* Progressive Conservative Party: "Get It Done"
* New Democratic Party: "A Better Ontario for Everyone"
* Liberal Party: "A New Team for a New Ontario"
* Green Party: "A Better Future for All"

## Debates

Several debates were held during the campaign period, including a televised leaders' debate on May 16, 2022. The debate was moderated by Steve Paikin and featured the leaders of the PCs, NDP, Liberals, and Greens.

## Issues

Several issues dominated the campaign period, including the economy, healthcare, education, and the environment. The PCs focused on their economic record and promised to continue to support businesses and individuals. The NDP focused on their plan to improve healthcare and education, while the Liberals emphasized the need for a more progressive approach to government. The Greens focused on their plan to address climate change and protect the environment.

## Summary

The campaign period was marked by a series of debates and the release of party platforms. The PCs emphasized their economic record, while the NDP and Liberals focused on their plans to improve healthcare and education. The Greens emphasized the need for action on climate change.

## Endorsements

Several organizations and individuals endorsed parties and candidates during the campaign period. These included the Ontario Federation of Labour, which endorsed the NDP, and the Ontario Chamber of Commerce, which endorsed the PCs.

# Opinion Polls

## Campaign polls

Several polls were conducted during the campaign period, including a poll by Ipsos, which found that the PCs were leading the NDP by 10 points. Another poll by Abacus Data found that the PCs were leading the NDP by 12 points.

## Pre-campaign polls

Several polls were conducted before the campaign period, including a poll by Forum Research, which found that the PCs were leading the NDP by 15 points. Another poll by Mainstreet Research found that the PCs were leading the NDP by 18 points.

# Results

## Synopsis of results

The 2022 Ontario general election resulted in a PC majority government, with the PCs winning 83 seats. The NDP won 31 seats, the Liberals won 8 seats, and the Greens won 1 seat. The PCs also won the popular vote, with 40.5% of the total vote.

## Post-election pendulum

The post-election pendulum shows that the PCs won several seats that were previously held by the NDP and Liberals. The NDP also won several seats that were previously held by the Liberals.

## Results summary by region

The results of the election varied by region. In Northern Ontario, the PCs won 13 seats, while the NDP won 5 seats. In Eastern Ontario, the PCs won 15 seats, while the Liberals won 2 seats. In Central Ontario, the PCs won 23 seats, while the NDP won 7 seats. In the Greater Toronto Area, the PCs won 31 seats, while the NDP won 10 seats.

## Detailed results

The detailed results of the election show that the PCs won several seats by large margins. The NDP also won several seats by large margins, including the riding of Toronto-Danforth, which was won by Peter Tabuns.

## Summary analysis

The results of the election show that the PCs won a majority government, with a significant lead over the NDP. The Liberals and Greens also won several seats, but were unable to make significant gains.

## Most marginal 2-way and 3-way contests

Several ridings were won by small margins, including the riding of Ottawa West-Nepean, which was won by the PCs by 0.4%. Another riding, Mississauga-Malton, was won by the NDP by 0.6%.

## Significant results among independent and minor party candidates

Several independent and minor party candidates won significant numbers of votes, including the Ontario Party, which won 2.1% of the total vote.

## Seats changing hands

Several seats changed hands during the election, including the riding of Brampton East, which was won by the PCs after being held by the NDP.

# References

## Opinion poll sources

Several opinion poll sources were used to report on the election, including Ipsos, Abacus Data, Forum Research, and Mainstreet Research.

# External links

Several external links were used to report on the election, including the website of Elections Ontario and the websites of the PCs, NDP, Liberals, and Greens.

Vaathi

Vaathi is a 2023 Indian Tamil-language action drama film written and directed by Venky Atluri. The film stars Dhanush and Samyuktha Menon in the lead roles, with Sai Kumar, Tanikella Bharani, and Samuthirakani in supporting roles. The film's production was handled by Sithara Entertainments and Fortune Four Cinemas.

#Plot

The film's plot revolves around the life of a young man named Balamurugan, played by Dhanush, who becomes a teacher in a government school in a small town. Balamurugan is a determined and passionate individual who wants to make a difference in the lives of his students. However, he soon realizes that the education system in the town is flawed and corrupt, with students being forced to pay exorbitant fees and bribe officials to pass their exams.

Determined to bring about a change, Balamurugan decides to take matters into his own hands and starts a crusade against the corrupt education system. He inspires his students to stand up for their rights and fight against the injustices they face. Along the way, he faces numerous challenges and obstacles, including threats from powerful officials and politicians who are determined to silence him.

As Balamurugan's movement gains momentum, he becomes a thorn in the side of the corrupt officials and politicians, who will stop at nothing to destroy him. The film's climax features an intense showdown between Balamurugan and his enemies, with the fate of the town's education system hanging in the balance.

* Samyuktha Menon as Meenakshi
* Sai Kumar as Sathya Moorthy

The film's director, Venky Atluri, had previously worked with Dhanush on the film "Thanga Magan". The film's script was written by Atluri, who was inspired by real-life events and his own experiences as a teacher.

##Filming

Principal photography for the film began in January 2022, with the film's team shooting in various locations across Tamil Nadu. The film's cinematography was handled by J. Yuvraj, who had previously worked on films such as "Kaatru Veliyidai" and "Gorilla". The film's editing was handled by Navin Nooli, who had previously worked on films such as "Jai Lava Kusa" and "Vinaya Vidheya Rama".

#Music

The film's soundtrack was composed by G. V. Prakash Kumar, who had previously worked with Dhanush on films such as "Polladhavan" and "Aadukalam". The film's score was composed by Kumar, who also sang several songs for the film. The film's lyrics were written by Kabilan and Vivek.

#Release

##Theatrical

The film was released in theaters on February 17, 2023, in Tamil Nadu and other parts of India. The film received a U/A certificate from the Central Board of Film Certification.

##Home media

The film's satellite rights were sold to Sun TV, while the film's digital rights were sold to Amazon Prime Video. The film was released on Amazon Prime Video on March 17, 2023.

#Reception

The film received generally positive reviews from critics, with many praising Dhanush's performance and the film's message. The film's climax was also widely praised, with many calling it one of the most intense and emotional climaxes in recent Tamil cinema.

However, the film also received some criticism, with some critics calling it predictable and formulaic. The film's pacing was also criticized, with some calling it slow and uneven.

* The film's script was written by Venky Atluri, who was inspired by real-life events and his own experiences as a teacher.

Joe Biden Classified Documents Incident

The Joe Biden classified documents incident refers to the discovery of classified documents in the possession of Joe Biden, the 46th President of the United States, at various locations, including his home in Wilmington, Delaware, and his office in Washington, D.C. The incident has sparked controversy and investigations, with implications for Biden's presidency and the handling of classified information.

# Background

As Vice President under Barack Obama, Joe Biden had access to sensitive and classified information. After leaving office in 2017, Biden maintained a office at the Penn Biden Center for Diplomacy and Global Engagement, a think tank located in Washington, D.C. The center was affiliated with the University of Pennsylvania, where Biden was a professor. Biden's office at the center was used to store documents and other materials related to his work as Vice President.

# Discoveries and other developments

## First batch of documents

In November 2022, Biden's lawyers discovered a batch of classified documents at the Penn Biden Center. The documents were found in a locked cabinet in Biden's office, and they were reportedly related to Biden's work as Vice President. The discovery was made by Biden's lawyers, who were packing up his office at the center.

## DOJ letter to Bob Bauer

On November 9, 2022, the Department of Justice (DOJ) sent a letter to Bob Bauer, Biden's lawyer, requesting that the documents be turned over to the National Archives and Records Administration (NARA). The letter stated that the documents were subject to the Presidential Records Act, which requires that presidential records be preserved and turned over to NARA.

## Second batch of documents

On December 20, 2022, Biden's lawyers discovered a second batch of classified documents at Biden's home in Wilmington, Delaware. The documents were found in a room in Biden's garage, and they were reportedly related to Biden's work as Vice President.

## FBI search of Biden's Wilmington home

On January 20, 2023, the FBI conducted a search of Biden's home in Wilmington, Delaware. The search was reportedly related to the discovery of the second batch of classified documents. The FBI seized several boxes of documents and other materials during the search.

## Other searches

In addition to the search of Biden's home, the FBI also searched his office at the Penn Biden Center. The search was reportedly related to the discovery of the first batch of classified documents.

# Initial responses

## Biden and his legal team

Biden and his legal team have maintained that the discovery of the classified documents was an honest mistake. Biden's lawyers have stated that they are cooperating fully with the investigation and are working to turn over all relevant documents to NARA.

## Elected officials

### Republican elected officials

Republican elected officials have been critical of Biden's handling of the classified documents. Some have called for Biden to be investigated and potentially charged with a crime. Others have accused Biden of hypocrisy, noting that he had previously criticized former President Donald Trump for his handling of classified documents.

### Democratic elected officials

Democratic elected officials have been more supportive of Biden, with many expressing confidence that he will be cleared of any wrongdoing. Some have noted that the discovery of the classified documents was an honest mistake and that Biden is cooperating fully with the investigation.

## Media analysis

The media has had a mixed reaction to the discovery of the classified documents. Some outlets have been critical of Biden's handling of the documents, while others have noted that the discovery was an honest mistake.

## Misinformation

There has been some misinformation spread about the discovery of the classified documents. Some have falsely claimed that Biden intentionally hid the documents or that he was trying to destroy evidence.

## Discovery of classified documents at Mike Pence's residence

In January 2023, it was reported that classified documents had been found at the residence of former Vice President Mike Pence. The discovery was seen as a potential embarrassment for Pence, who had previously criticized Biden for his handling of classified documents.

# Investigations

## Special counsel

In January 2023, Attorney General Merrick Garland appointed a special counsel to investigate the discovery of the classified documents. The special counsel, Robert Hur, is a former U.S. Attorney who has experience handling sensitive investigations.

### Decision that charges were unwarranted

In June 2023, the special counsel announced that he had completed his investigation and had determined that charges were unwarranted. The special counsel found that Biden had not intentionally mishandled the classified documents and that the discovery was an honest mistake.

### Comments on Biden's memory

The special counsel also made comments about Biden's memory, noting that he had struggled to recall details about the discovery of the classified documents. However, the special counsel found that Biden's memory issues were not relevant to the investigation.

## Congressional

In addition to the special counsel's investigation, Congress has also launched its own investigation into the discovery of the classified documents. The investigation is being led by the House Oversight Committee, which has subpoenaed Biden's lawyers and other witnesses.

2023 PDC World Cup of Darts

The 2023 PDC World Cup of Darts was the 14th edition of the PDC World Cup of Darts, a major darts tournament organized by the Professional Darts Corporation (PDC). The event took place from June 15 to June 18, 2023, at the Eissporthalle in Frankfurt, Germany.

# Format

The 2023 PDC World Cup of Darts followed the same format as the previous year's tournament. The competition featured 40 teams from around the world, each representing a different nation. The teams were divided into 10 groups of four teams each, with the top two teams from each group advancing to the knockout stage. The knockout stage consisted of a single-elimination bracket, with the teams competing in a best-of-5 legs format in the second round and quarterfinals, and a best-of-7 legs format in the semifinals and final.

## Group Stage Draw

The draw for the group stage took place on May 24, 2023, at the PDC headquarters in the United Kingdom. The teams were seeded based on their performance in the 2022 PDC World Darts Championship, with the top 10 seeded teams being drawn into separate groups. The remaining 30 teams were drawn into the groups randomly.

## Knockout Stage Draw

The draw for the knockout stage took place after the completion of the group stage. The winners of each group were drawn against the runners-up from a different group, with the top seed playing the lowest-ranked runner-up and so on.

# Prize Money

The total prize fund for the 2023 PDC World Cup of Darts was £450,000, with the winning team receiving £70,000. The runner-up team received £40,000, while the semifinalists received £20,000 each. The teams that were eliminated in the group stage received £10,000 each.

2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup qualification

The 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup qualification will be a men's under-17 football competition to determine the participating teams of the 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup.

# Format changes

The 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup qualification format has undergone changes compared to the previous edition. A total of 45 teams will participate in the qualification process, divided into 10 groups of 4-5 teams each. The top team from each group and the 5 best runners-up will qualify for the 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup.

# Draw

The draw for the qualification groups was held on 24 June 2022 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. The 45 participating teams were divided into 5 pots based on their performance in the 2018 AFC U-16 Championship and the 2020 AFC U-16 Championship qualification. The teams were then drawn into 10 groups, with the host team of each group being determined by the AFC.

# Player eligibility

Players born on or after 1 January 2006 are eligible to participate in the 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup qualification.

# Format

The qualification process will consist of a group stage, with each team playing the other teams in their group once. The top team from each group and the 5 best runners-up will advance to the 2023 AFC U-17 Asian Cup.

## Tiebreakers

If two or more teams are tied on points, the following tiebreakers will be applied:

* Goal difference in all group matches
* Greater number of goals scored in all group matches
* Points obtained in the matches played between the teams in question
* Goal difference in the matches played between the teams in question
* Greater number of goals scored in the matches played between the teams in question
* Drawing of lots

article:
Battle of Kapyong

The Battle of Kapyong was a pivotal battle fought during the Korean War, taking place from April 22 to 25, 1951. The battle saw Australian, Canadian, and New Zealand forces, as part of the 1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (3 RAR), 2nd Battalion, Princess Patricia's Canadian Light Infantry (2 PPCLI), and 16th Field Regiment, Royal New Zealand Artillery, respectively, defend against a massive Chinese Spring Offensive. The battle is widely regarded as one of the most significant victories for the United Nations Command during the war.

#Background

##Military situation

In the spring of 1951, the Korean War had been ongoing for nearly a year. The United Nations Command, led by General Douglas MacArthur, had been pushing the North Korean and Chinese forces back, but the latter had regrouped and were preparing to launch a massive counterattack. The Chinese Spring Offensive, also known as the "Fifth Phase Campaign," aimed to drive the United Nations forces back and capture the South Korean capital, Seoul.

#Chinese Spring Offensive

##Preparations

In preparation for the offensive, the Chinese People's Volunteer Army (PVA) had amassed a massive force of over 300,000 soldiers, supported by artillery, tanks, and airpower. The PVA had also been reinforced with fresh troops, including the 63rd Army, which had been withdrawn from the front lines and retrained.

##Launch of Chinese Spring Offensive

On April 22, 1951, the Chinese Spring Offensive was launched, with PVA forces attacking along a 40-mile front. The initial assault was aimed at the South Korean 6th Division, which was quickly overwhelmed. As the South Korean forces retreated, the United Nations Command realized that the PVA was pushing towards the strategic Kapyong Valley, a vital transportation route that connected the 1st Marine Division with the 24th Infantry Division.

##South Korean withdrawal, 22–23 April 1951

As the PVA pushed forward, the South Korean 6th Division withdrew in disarray, leaving a 10-mile gap in the United Nations line. The Australian 3 RAR, which had been holding a defensive position on Hill 504, was ordered to fall back and take up a new position on the high ground overlooking the Kapyong Valley.

#Australian 3 RAR defence of Hill 504, 23–24 April 1951

##Night battle

On the night of April 23, 1951, the Australian 3 RAR took up its new position on Hill 504, which was a vital defensive location overlooking the Kapyong Valley. As the PVA forces approached, the Australians prepared for a night battle, digging in and laying down a defensive perimeter. At around 10 pm, the PVA launched a massive assault on the Australian position, with waves of soldiers attacking the hill. The Australians held firm, using their artillery and machine guns to devastating effect.

##Day battle

As the sun rose on April 24, 1951, the battle raged on, with the PVA forces launching repeated attacks on the Australian position. The Australians, supported by artillery and airpower, held their ground, inflicting heavy casualties on the PVA. Despite being vastly outnumbered, the Australians managed to repel wave after wave of attacks, with the PVA suffering heavy losses.

##3 RAR withdraws

As the day wore on, the Australians realized that they were in danger of being cut off and surrounded by the PVA. At around 4 pm, the 3 RAR was ordered to withdraw from Hill 504 and fall back to a new position on the high ground overlooking the Kapyong Valley. The Australians withdrew in good order, leaving behind a trail of destruction and chaos.

#Canadian 2 PPCLI last stand on Hill 677, 24–25 April 1951

##Preparations

As the Australians withdrew from Hill 504, the Canadian 2 PPCLI took up a defensive position on Hill 677, which was a vital location overlooking the Kapyong Valley. The Canadians prepared for a last stand, digging in and laying down a defensive perimeter. The PVA, sensing victory, launched a massive assault on the Canadian position.

##Night battle

On the night of April 24, 1951, the PVA launched a fierce assault on the Canadian position, with waves of soldiers attacking the hill. The Canadians held firm, using their artillery and machine guns to devastating effect. Despite being vastly outnumbered, the Canadians managed to repel wave after wave of attacks, with the PVA suffering heavy losses.

##Final 2 PPCLI Operations

As the night wore on, the Canadians realized that they were in danger of being overrun. At around 2 am on April 25, 1951, the 2 PPCLI launched a final counterattack, using every available man to push the PVA back. The Canadians managed to hold their ground, but at a terrible cost. As the sun rose on April 25, 1951, the Canadians withdrew from Hill 677, having inflicted heavy casualties on the PVA.

#Aftermath

##Summary and casualties

The Battle of Kapyong was a pivotal victory for the United Nations Command, with the Australians and Canadians inflicting heavy casualties on the PVA. The battle saw the PVA suffer over 10,000 casualties, while the United Nations forces lost around 700 men. The battle marked a turning point in the war, as the PVA never fully recovered from the losses suffered during the Chinese Spring Offensive.

##Awards

The Battle of Kapyong saw numerous awards and decorations bestowed upon the Australians and Canadians. The 3 RAR was awarded the United States Presidential Unit Citation, while the 2 PPCLI was awarded the United States Presidential Unit Citation and the British Distinguished Service Order.

##Subsequent operations

Following the Battle of Kapyong, the United Nations Command launched a series of operations aimed at pushing the PVA back. The Australians and Canadians played a key role in these operations, which saw the PVA slowly pushed back across the 38th parallel.
